section.title: Overview
section.para: Job Pre-Conditions Scripts allow you to control which Jobs are run within a Workflow and which are skipped. Here are a few examples of situations where this kind of control could be handy:

listitem.para: You have a large number of Projects that use the same Deploy Workflow but some Projects have a documentation Artifact that needs to be deployed while others don’t. Rather than maintain two separate Workflows with only one additional Job (deploying the documentation), you could use a Job Pre-Condition Script to only run a "Documentation Deploy" Job for Projects that actually supply a documentation artifact.

You have a Job that should only be automatically run in specific environments (such as database migrations or cache restartrs) in Development and QA, but not in Production. You can use a Job Pre-Condition to check the target Environment to see if these Jobs should be run or not.

Deployers want to be able to choose, at Deploy time, which Artifacts get deployed to avoid the time spent to deploy components that haven't changed. Workflow Properties can be set up to give Deployers that option and a Job Pre-Condition script can insepct the value, existence or non-existence of those properties and act accordingly.

section.para: This document aims to give you details of how Job Pre-Conditions work and how to write your own.

section.title: Creating Job Pre-Condition Scripts
section.para: To create Job Pre-Conditions you'll need access to the System tab. See the official Anthill Pro documentation for information on managing permissions.
To create a new Job Pre-Condition:

listitem.para: In the "Script Library" section click on “Job Pre-Condition”.
Choose a "Language". (Beanshell for the provided examples)

section.title: Job Pre-Condition Criteria Objects
section.para: As the description above the "Script" text area states, the script needs to return a Criteria object. AntHill Pro will take the Criteria object you return and call its “matches” method. If the method returns true the Job will be run. If it returns false, the Job will be skipped.

section.title: Which Criteria Class?
section.para: A quick look at the AntHill Pro Remoting API might lead you to believe you're working with the Criteria class listed there, but that class lives in com.urbancode.anthill3.domain.script.agentfilter.criteria.

For Job Pre-Conditions you want the Criteria class in the package in com.urbancode.logic. This class is not listed in the Remoting or Scripting APIs. However two of its subclasses are:
com.urbancode.anthill3.domain.script.job.JobStatus
com.urbancode.anthill3.domain.script.job.Property

section.title: JobStatus Class
section.para: JobStatus provides a number of static methods that look at the status of other jobs in the current workflow. You can look at the status of:

listitem.para: All the Jobs in the workflow
Ancestor Jobs - Jobs that occurred before the current one, if any
Parent Job - The Job immediately before the current one, if any
Iterated Jobs - Completed Jobs in the same iteration as the current Job, if any
Completed Jobs - All jobs that have run in the workflow, regardless of their “ancestry”

section.para: Additionally, you can base your decision if a job has one particular status or if its status is in an array of acceptable statuses.

section.title: JobStatusEnum
section.para: Before we continue, we need to talk about the status of Jobs. After Jobs are executed (or skipped because of a Job Pre-condition) they are give one of the following statuses from the JobStatusEnum enumeration:

row.entry: Dependencies were resolved but the Workflow is configured to warn on conflict.
The job was run but failed.
The job was run but aborted by a user.
The job was run but took longer than the Job’s timeout period.
The job was determined to be not needed by a Job Pre-condition and skipped.

section.title: Property Class
section.para: Sometimes you want to control the execution of Jobs with properties. This is where the Property class steps in. You’ll be using the one in com.urbancode.anthill3.domain.script, not the one in com.urbancode.anthill3.domain.property.

From the Remoting API: “A Criteria for making decisions base on properties and property values in the current context. The properties are looked up using PropertyEvaluator so the things holding properties that are examined are determined where this is executed and what is in the context.”

section.title: Property Static Methods
section.para: Property provides a number of static methods that can tell you if a property exists, if it has a certain value, if it’s value is in a list of values or if the value matches a regular expression. Note: propName is always a String, value is a String and values is an Array of Strings.

row.entry: Create a Criteria that only returns true if...
the named property is not defined.
the named property is defined and has the exact value as one of the given values.
the named property is not defined or the property is defined and its value is not the exact value of one of the given values.
the named property is defined and has the exact given value.
the named property is not defined or the property is defined and its value is not the exact given value.
the named property is defined and the property value matches the regular expression given.
the named property is defined and the property value matches on of the regular expressions given.
the named property is not defined or the property is defined and its value does not match the regular expression given.
the named property is not defined or the property is defined and its value does not match the regular expressions given.

section.title: Logic
section.para: Often you will need to combine the results of JobStatus and Property calls. The Logic class provides a few static methods to help you do this. Unfortunately this is another class that does appear in the public APIs - it comes from a dependency of AntHill Pro, not AHP itself.

section.title: Logic Static Methods
section.para: Here are the static methods it provides:

row.entry: Create a Criteria that only returns true if...

section.para: This is very useful for Jobs beyond the first one in the workflow where we care about the jobs that ran before the current one. For example, we may want to run a particular Job if a property is set to true AND if all previous Jobs were successful as well. For that we can use Logic.and to check the Criteria objects returned by both JobStatus and Property methods.

section.title: Custom Criteria Classes
section.para: AntHill Pro comes with a number of Job Pre-Condition Scripts already set up that cover most of the common scenarios regarding Job Stauses. If you need to support logic outside of what JobStatus and Property provide then you need to make your own Criteria class. You can do this by creating one on the fly and returning it in your script. You need only implement a method named matches(Object) which needs to return a boolean.

Return "true" if you want the Job in question to run. The Job will run and return one of the JobStatusEnum values other than NOT_NEEDED, depending on its success. Return "false" if you want it to be skipped. It will be given the status JobStatusEnum.NOT_NEEDED.

section.title: Combining Stock and Custom Criteria Classes
section.para: Just as you might want to combine a JobStatus and Property Criteria class, you might want to combine them with your own Custom Criteria, or multiple Custom Criterias. This is another place you can make use of the Logic static methods.

section.title: Context Is King
section.para: So it’s great that you can use the stock Criteria classes, create you own custom ones, and even combine them in various ways, but often you will need to base your decision on information beyond only the status of other jobs and the value of properties.

Several "Lookup" classes provide a getCurrent() method that returns an object in the context of the currently running Workflow that can help you create your own logic. Here are a few that might be useful:
The Scripting API lists a number of other methods for these Lookup classes so it’s worth looking through the documentation for others.

section.title: Run if a Property has a certain value
Run if a Property does not have a set of values
Run if previous Jobs were successful/not needed and Property exists
Run if previous Jobs were success/not needed and check properties
Run if Build Life has a certain Status
Run if Build Request Source is of a certain type
Run if executing in a certain Environment
Leverage Properties for Flexible Code
section.para: While it would be tempting to use job preconditions in a Library Workflow to make exceptions for specific projects (by using something like if (ProjectLookup.getProject.getName().equals("foo")) the best practice would be to set a more generic property on those projects and check for that property instead. That way, when copying the project to create something similar the precondition will not need to be updated to check for additional Project names.

section.title: Don’t Throw Exceptions to Fail the Workflow
section.para: Job Pre-Conditions help decide whether a Job should run or not. They are not meant to affect the overall success of the Job - that responsibility falls to Job Steps.
